In Italia mappati 29 impianti eolici, di cui 7 nel 2025, al centro della guida Parchi del Vento 2025

9 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

9 Ottobre 2025

Comunicati stampa

Rinnovabili

Viaggio tra i “Parchi del Vento” della Penisola: 29 gli impianti eolici selezionati e mappati in Italia da Legambiente, di cui 7 nel 2025, raccontati nella quarta edizione della guida turistica “Parchi del Vento”.  Legambiente: “Gli impianti eolici, se ben fatti e integrati con il territorio, possono essere anche un importante volano turistico. Fondamentale realizzare nuovi impianti, a terra e in mare, snellendo e velocizzando gli iter normativi e coinvolgendo le comunità locali”.

Dal cuore dell’Alto Molise, tra le creste appenniniche, alla Valle del Belice, in Sicilia, passando all’entroterra lucano e pugliese, l’Italia dei “Parchi del Vento” continua a riservare soprese. Qui, fuori dai circuiti turistici più frequentati, si possono scoprire territori dove gli impianti eolici non solo sono laboratori di transizione ecologica ma anche attrattori di turismo. A raccontarlo sono i 29 impianti selezionati da Legambiente, di cui 7 nel 2025, al centro della quarta edizione della guida turistica “Parchi del Vento”, realizzata dall’associazione ambientalista con il contributo di Agsm AIM, RWE, Winderg, il patrocinio di ANEV, e presentata oggi alla Fiera Internazionale del Turismo a Rimini. Una guida unica in Italia che, dal nord al sud della Penisola, ben racconta il connubio vincente tra innovazione, energia pulita e turismo attraverso la formula del viaggio. Sono tanti e diversi i luoghi dove si possono vedere da vicino questi impianti, scoprendone il loro funzionamento, e allo stesso tempo visitando territori a piedi, in bici o a cavallo e ricchi di storia, cultura, bellezze e prelibatezze culinarie. I sette nuovi impianti eolici (2 in Molise, 1 in Puglia, 2  in Basilicata, 2 in Sicilia,) inseriti nella guida 2025 e che si aggiungono ai 22 censiti nelle precedenti edizioni, ne sono un perfetto esempio: il parco eolico di Vastogirardi, lungo le creste dell’Appennino molisano, in provincia di Isernia, e quello di Castelmauro in provincia di Campobasso circondato da verde e colline intervallate da piccoli borghi, in Puglia l’impianto eolico Valleverde a Bovino (FG), comune annoverato tra i borghi più belli d’Italia, quello di Partanna (TP), nel cuore della Valle Belice, e quello di Gangi, in provincia di Palermo, tra le Madonie e i monti Nebrodi, e poi in Basilicata l’impianto eolico di “Santa Tecla”, ad Avigliano (PZ), e quello di Tivano, a Lavello (PZ). Nelle pagine della guida, oltre alla scheda di presentazione di ogni impianto, si possono trovare info su come arrivare nei luoghi, cosa visitare, dove andare a mangiare, quali percorsi e sentieri fare, il tutto insieme a storie e aneddoti dei territori.
I commenti  
“Per contrastare l’emergenza climatica e migliorare le condizioni sociali del nostro Paese – commenta Katiuscia Eroe responsabile energia di Legambiente – è fondamentale non solo far crescere la produzione da rinnovabili e rendere finalmente il nostro sistema energetico libero da carbone, petrolio e gas, escludendo l’inutile e costoso ritorno al nucleare, ma anche fare in modo che queste tecnologie portino sempre più vantaggi ai territori e alle comunità. Gli impianti eolici non sono né ecomostri né impianti mostruosi come affermato da alcune amministrazioni locali. Con la nostra guida turistica Parchi del Vento, grazie alla collaborazione di diversi partner, raccontiamo a cittadini, turisti, curiosi ma anche imprese e amministrazioni come ciò sia possibile perché un parco eolico, se ben integrato con il territorio, può essere un volano per attirare curiosità verso i territori in cui sono ospitati, valorizzando le attività esistenti. Non dimentichiamo inoltre che, per completare la rivoluzione energetica, è fondamentale spingere sempre più sulle rinnovabili snellendo gli iter normativi e coinvolgendo le comunità locali”.
“Intorno ai parchi eolici che raccontiamo all’interno della Guida Parchi del Vento – aggiunge Sebastiano Venneri, responsabile turismo di Legambiente– stanno nascendo sempre di più opportunità interessanti, come percorsi ciclopedonali, passeggiate a cavallo, il passaggio del Giro d’Italia. Ma anche impianti perfettamente integrati con vitigni e uliveti e che permettono di riscoprire tradizioni e culture storiche, ormai dimenticati da molti. Questi impianti sono la dimostrazione che integrare nuovi impianti nel paesaggio è non solo possibile ma anche una sfida che può essere affrontata solo con il consenso delle comunità attraverso forme innovative e affascinanti di valorizzazione delle risorse locali”.
Dati eolico in Italia
Legambiente ricorda che in Italia l’eolico svolge un ruolo sempre più rilevante, arrivando ad agosto 2025 a quota 13.356 MW di potenza installata, di cui 685 realizzati nel 2024 e 337 nel 2025, in grado di produrre, nel 2024, complessivamente 22.068 GWh/a di energia elettrica, pari al fabbisogno di circa 8,1 milioni di famiglie. Un numero che negli ultimi vent’anni è cresciuto passando da 1.131 MW del 2004 ai numeri attuali, permettendo a questa tecnologia di produrre il 17,2% del totale prodotto da fonti rinnovabili e di fornire un contributo rispetto ai consumi complessivi italiani pari al 7%. Per accelerare la diffusione dell’eolico, sia a terra sia a mare, occorre però snellire e velocizzare gli iter autorizzativi coinvolgendo sempre più comunità e territori, semplificando anche la normativa per il repowering degli impianti esistenti.
Focus Parchi eolici. Molise
Tra i comuni di Castelmauro e Roccavivara, nella provincia di Campobasso, si trova il parco eolico di Castelmauro (CB) di Enel Green Power Italia situato a 800 metri sul livello del mare e circondato da verde e colline. Entrato in funzione nel 2022, l’impianto dispone di 7 aerogeneratori, ognuno da 4,2 MW, per una capacità installata complessiva di 29,4 MW. Nel primo periodo di esercizio ha prodotto in media oltre 55.000 MWh di energia pulita all’anno, fornendo energia pulita e rinnovabile a 3.700 famiglie (circa un quarto delle famiglie del Molise) ed evitando l’immissione in atmosfera di 4.384 tonnellate di CO2.  Merita di essere vistato il borgo di Castelmauro tra dolci colline punteggiate da ulivi, vigneti e boschi secolari, e il castello medievale. Sempre in Molise, lungo le creste dell’Appennino, si trovano i due parchi eolici contigui di Vastogirardi 1 e 2 di Enel Green Power Italia, immersi in un paesaggio ancora integro. Qui le 18 turbine per complessivi 26,35 MW, seguono il ritmo del territorio. Gli aerogeneratori, distribuiti su creste tra i 1.240 e i 1.270 metri sul livello del mare a cavallo tra il Comune di Vastogirardi e quello di Capracotta. Piccoli comuni ricchi di storia e bellezze naturalistiche, come il bosco di Montedimezzo, riconosciuto come parte della Riserva MaB UNESCO: 276 ettari di cerrete e faggete che compongono un ecosistema intatto, percorso da sentieri, abitato da caprioli, lupi e rapaci.
Basilicata
Due i parchi eolici lucani mappati quest’anno nella Guida. Il Parco eolico di Tivano, a Lavello (PZ) composto da sette aerogeneratori, per una potenza complessiva di 14 MW. Insieme, queste moderne turbine producono circa 31 GWh annui di energia pulita, sufficiente a coprire il fabbisogno energetico di circa 10.000 famiglie. Da visitare Lavello, terzo comune più popoloso della provincia di Potenza, ricco di storia e cultura, e celebre per il suo Carnevale. Nell’entroterra lucano, tra terreni argillosi che hanno ospitato storie, pastori e briganti, si erge il Parco eolico di Avigliano capace di produrre oltre 3.500 MWh anno di energia pulita. Denominato “Santa Tecla”, come la storica località che lo ospita, l’impianto ha avuto anche un importante risvolto sociale: dalla sua entrata in funzione, la società Winderg finanzia periodicamente l’APD Atletico Avigliano, squadra di calcio femminile che milita nel campionato di Eccellenza. Avigliano si distingue anche per il contesto naturalistico che lo circonda tra cui anche la sorgente del torrente Tiera, affluente del Basento.
Puglia
In Puglia l’impianto eolico Valleverde, nel Comune di Bovino, in provincia di Foggia, è tra i più recenti ed innovativi nel territorio. Il parco è composto da nove aerogeneratori per una potenza complessiva di 63 MW, in grado di generare 141 GWh annui di energia elettrica, pari al fabbisogno di 45.000 famiglie. Con i suoi 2.893 abitanti, Bovino rientra tra i Borghi più Belli d’Italia e, dal 2013, ha ottenuto la Bandiera Arancione del Touring Club Italiano. Da visitare anche il Castello Ducale.
Sicilia
Nella Valle del Belice, nel Comune di Partanna, l’impianto eolico Partanna, inaugurato da Enel Green Power Italia nel 2021, è formato da sei turbine da 2,4 MW di potenza ciascuna per un totale di 14,4 MW in grado di generare 40 GWh anno di energia pulita, pari al fabbisogno di 10.000 famiglie. Un parco eolico aperto, senza barriere, meta di ciclisti e famiglie. Altro impianto siculo censito nel 2025 è quello di Gangi (PA) che si sviluppa sul crinale del Monte Zimmara a 1250 metri sul livello del mare. È costituito da 32 aerogeneratori, disposti in modo da risultare il più possibile omogenei in altezza, ognuno con una potenza di 850 kW, per una capacità installata complessiva di 27,2 MW. L’impianto negli ultimi 5 anni, dal 2020 al 2024, ha prodotto in media 56 GWh l’anno, sufficienti a soddisfare il fabbisogno energetico di 21.000 famiglie. Inoltre, l’energia pulita prodotta dal vento permette di evitare l’immissione in atmosfera di 42.000 tonnellate di anidride carbonica (CO2) ogni anno. Da visitare il piccolo comune di Gangi, un museo a cielo aperto, insignito nel 2014 come Borgo più bello d’Italia, e circondato dal Parco delle Madonie e da innumerevoli sentieri e percorsi come quello geoturistico del centro storico di Gangi, ideato nel 2011.

items.title: Agenzia delle Entrate, spostati i rimborsi del 730 a marzo 2026: cosa succederà
items.description:
L’Agenzia delle Entrate ha ufficializzato le nuove tempistiche per i rimborsi IRPEF derivanti dalla presentazione del Modello 730.
L'articolo Agenzia
items.body: Sostenibilità Agenzia delle Entrate, spostati i rimborsi del 730 a marzo 2026: cosa succederà    Roberto Arciola    Ottobre 9, 2025     Calendario e modalità di accredito dei rimborsi 730- greenstyle.it  L’Agenzia delle Entrate ha ufficializzato le nuove tempistiche per i rimborsi IRPEF derivanti dalla presentazione del Modello 730.Le scadenze per l’accredito dei rimborsi variano sensibilmente in base alla modalità di presentazione e alla presenza o meno di un sostituto d’imposta.I contribuenti che hanno presentato il Modello 730 tramite un sostituto d’imposta (datore di lavoro o ente pensionistico) entro il termine del 20 giugno 2025 riceveranno il rimborso IRPEF in modo tempestivo. In questi casi, l’accredito avviene direttamente in busta paga nel mese di luglio o, per i pensionati, nel cedolino pensione di agosto. Questa modalità garantisce un accesso rapido alle somme spettanti e consente anche l’utilizzo del credito in compensazione per il pagamento di altre imposte.Tuttavia, per chi ha superato il termine di presentazione o presenta un credito superiore a 4.000 euro, l’Agenzia delle Entrate è obbligata a effettuare controlli fiscali preventivi approfonditi per verificare la correttezza del credito dichiarato. Di conseguenza, l’accredito del rimborso sarà posticipato a marzo 2026, con un ritardo che interessa sia le dichiarazioni presentate con sostituto d’imposta sia quelle inviate autonomamente o tramite intermediari abilitati come CAF o professionisti fiscali.Per i pensionati che presentano la dichiarazione dopo il 20 giugno, invece, il rimborso sarà accreditato nel cedolino di settembre anziché in quello di agosto, con un impatto diretto sulla liquidità disponibile.Situazioni senza sostituto d’imposta e altri casi particolariI contribuenti privi di un sostituto d’imposta devono ricevere il rimborso direttamente dall’Agenzia delle Entrate. Se l’Agenzia dispone delle coordinate bancarie o postali corrette, il pagamento viene effettuato entro sei mesi dalla scadenza di presentazione della dichiarazione o dalla data di trasmissione del modello, previa richiesta tramite PEC o procedura telematica. In assenza di tali coordinate, l’Agenzia invia un assegno vidimato di Poste Italiane all’indirizzo del contribuente, che potrà incassare la somma presso gli sportelli postali.Per i contribuenti che utilizzano il Modello Redditi precompilato (ex Unico), le modalità e i tempi di rimborso sono equiparati a quelli del Modello 730, con le stesse procedure di accredito e le medesime tempistiche. Importanza del rispetto delle scadenze e implicazioni fiscali – www.greenstyle.itL’Agenzia delle Entrate sottolinea l’importanza di rispettare le scadenze per la presentazione del Modello 730 per evitare ritardi e lunghe procedure di controllo che rallentano l’erogazione dei rimborsi IRPEF. La tempestività nella consegna della dichiarazione consente infatti un flusso finanziario più regolare e una miglior gestione della liquidità per i contribuenti.Il Modello 730, introdotto nel 1993 e successivamente evoluto con l’implementazione del 730 precompilato nel 2014, rappresenta uno strumento fondamentale per lavoratori dipendenti e pensionati per dichiarare i redditi e ottenere rimborsi fiscali in modo semplice e diretto. Grazie al supporto del sostituto d’imposta, il contribuente può evitare calcoli complessi e ricevere eventuali rimborsi direttamente in busta paga o nel cedolino pensionistico.In particolare, il modello 730 consente di dichiarare redditi di lavoro dipendente, pensioni, redditi da terreni e fabbricati, redditi di capitale, lavoro autonomo occasionale e altre tipologie di reddito assimilate, oltre a indicare oneri e spese che danno diritto a detrazioni fiscali. L’ampia gamma di spese detraibili comprende, tra le altre, quelle sanitarie, per l’istruzione, per mutui ipotecari, interventi di risparmio energetico, e contributi previdenziali.La gestione centralizzata da parte dell’Agenzia delle Entrate e l’adozione di procedure telematiche hanno consentito negli anni di migliorare la trasparenza e la regolarità delle operazioni di rimborso, sebbene permangano ritardi e verifiche rigorose in caso di crediti elevati o presentazioni tardive.Il rispetto delle norme e delle scadenze rappresenta quindi un elemento chiave per garantire un’esperienza efficiente e senza intoppi nel processo di rimborso IRPEF tramite Modello 730. INCONTRIAMOCI! CI TROVI NEL PADIGLIONE D5 | STAND 314						
				
				
				
																										
				
				
				
							Dal 4 al 7 novembre ritorna l’appuntamento con Ecomondo: non perdere gli appuntamenti dell’Area Forum CIB						
				
				
				
							Il CIB e le aziende Socie espositrici di Ecomondo 2025 animeranno insieme il palco dell’Area Forum, che potrai trovare alle spalle dello stand CIB (Padiglione D5 | Stand 314).						
				
					
		
					
		
				
				
					
			
						
		
				
				
				
						
					
			
						
				
							Martedì 4 novembre						
				
					
		
					
		
				
						
					
			
						
				
					
							
										
						
														
								14.00 - 15.30 La necessità di diffusione e le criticità di accesso alle tecnologie in agricoltura | EVENTO CIB

Il settore primario è chiamato a rispondere a diverse sfide: fornire cibo di qualità e produrlo in modo sostenibile; rispondere alla necessità di ridurre le emissioni e tutelare la fertilità dei suoli; implementare la produzione e l’utilizzo di fonti rinnovabili; interagire con sempre maggiori settori produttivi. Al contempo, il settore primario ha bisogno di misure che favoriscano il percorso di transizione agroecologica. In questo contesto, è necessario interrogarsi su come si possa agevolare l’accesso alle tecnologie disponibili per le numerose aziende agricole italiane che sono pronte a cogliere la sfida. La digestione anaerobica nel tempo ha dimostrato essere una tecnologia in grado di fare da volano per l’introduzione di altre tecnologie innovative nel contesto aziendale agricolo.  Il focus della conferenza è quello di offrire un approfondimento sul tema e rispondere alle domande e alle richieste del settore, proponendo comportamenti virtuosi e buone pratiche.Presidente di sessioneFabio Fava, Presidente CTS EcomondoProgrammaIntroduzione - Fabio Fava, Presidente CTS e Piero Gattoni, Presidente CIBLe misure a supporto della diffusione tecnologica: tra ricerca e applicazione - Angelo Frascarelli, Università degli Studi di Perugia; Paolo Menesatti, Direttore del CREA-IT e Cosimo Pacciani, Osservatorio Smart AgriFood del Politecnico di MilanoL’innovazione tecnologica e le necessità del mondo agricolo - Dialogo tra: Gianmichele Passarini, Vice Presidente CIA; Massimiliano Giansanti, Presidente Confagricoltura e Ettore Prandini, Presidente ColdirettiLe azioni del progetto di Farming for Future come volano per l’innovazione aziendale - Dialogo tra: Diana Lenzi, Presidente Fondazione Farming for Future; Davide Biagi, Soc. items.title: Un futuro sempre meno verde per la PAC
items.description:
Il Parlamento Europeo ha approvato oggi il pacchetto di “semplificazione” della PAC che prevede l’abolizione di molte norme ambientali. 
The post Un f
items.body:
Pandanews
 
 

 

 
 
 Categorie
 

 
 
 

 
 Con il voto in plenaria il Parlamento europeo ha votato a favore della proposta della Commissione europea di indebolire l'attuale Politica Agricola Comune
 
 
 

 

 
 
Le Associazioni: “Un autogol per il nostro futuro”

Con il voto in plenaria il Parlamento europeo ha votato a favore della proposta della Commissione europea di indebolire l’attuale Politica Agricola Comune (PAC), andando addirittura oltre. Abolendo alcune disposizioni fondamentali delle Buone Condizioni Agricole e Ambientali (GAEC)*, ha dato carta bianca alle pratiche agricole inquinanti e distruttive nel cuore delle aree protette.

Decisioni miopi contro l’ambiente

Le 13 associazioni che nei giorni scorsi avevano chiesto ai parlamentari europei di dire NO a questo provvedimento dichiarano: “Oggi il Parlamento europeo ha scelto, ancora una volta, di condannare l’agricoltura e gli agricoltori al fallimento totale. Decisioni miopi stanno sacrificando il nostro patrimonio naturale comune – praterie, habitat protetti e suoli sani – che sono fondamentali per l’agricoltura di oggi e di domani.”Il voto di oggi conferma la decisione della commissione AGRI del 24 settembre, il Parlamento europeo ha così indebolito le protezioni per i suoli e per gli ecosistemi, abolendo le misure contro l’erosione (GAEC 5) e eliminando le salvaguardie per le praterie Natura 2000 (GAEC 9), mettendo a rischio gli habitat più preziosi d’europa e decretando che le aziende agricole situate nei siti Natura 2000 sono di per sé e senza ulteriori condizioni conformi alla condizionalità della PAC.

Un passo indietro per la natura

“Ringraziamo i numerosi parlamentari italiani afferenti ai gruppi dei Verdi Europei, Left e S&D che hanno votato contro questi provvedimenti” aggiungono le associazioni.Avendo anche il Consiglio adottato la propria posizione su questo pacchetto di semplificazione, i negoziati trilaterali dovrebbero iniziare nelle prossime settimane per poi giungere entro l’anno all’adozione del provvedimento. Parallelamente, ricordano le associazioni, stanno proseguono le discussioni sulla proposta della Commissione relativa alla PAC post-2027, la cui proposta è tutt’altro che a favore di una transizione agroecologica.Per questo, concludono le associazioni: “ Chiediamo agli Stati membri e alla Commissione europea di fermare immediatamente questo pericoloso passo indietro per la natura durante i prossimi triloghi. Il futuro degli agricoltori, della natura e dei cittadini europei dipende da questo”.

items.title: Characterization of geothermal resources and estimation of power potential of Badrinath geothermal field northwest Himalaya India
items.body:
IntroductionThe transition to a carbon-free society depends on the prompt adoption of renewable energy sources (RES) to replace fossil fuels1. While wind and solar energy are cost-competitive, their intermittency limits their capacity to provide reliable baseload power2. Geothermal energy (GTE) emerges as a strong candidate, providing the reliability needed for a sustainable energy future2. Geothermal energy cuts greenhouse gas emissions, supporting United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) goals, and is a sustainable and eco-friendly source3,4. Geothermal energy offers a distinct advantage over other renewable sources because it provides baseload electricity and enables direct utilization5.These unique characteristics have contributed to a significant global increase in geothermal electricity generation and direct applications over the past few decades6,7,8. Geothermal systems are primarily formed because of exothermally heated groundwater driven by convection through fractures, high geothermal gradients, and heat sources such as active tectonic zones (e.g., the Himalayas), volcanic regions, radioactive decay in the Earth’s crust, plate boundaries (continental or divergent), and sedimentary basins9,10,11,12,13,14. India ranks first in energy consumption among developing nations15, and the financial burden of importing fossil fuels has become increasingly unsustainable16. Given the global urgency to address climate change and reduce fossil fuel dependency, the international community is rapidly transitioning to cleaner energy alternatives.The geothermal potential of the Himalayan region, particularly the Garhwal Himalaya, is closely associated with the Main Central Thrust (MCT), which functions as a deep-seated regional heat source9,11,17,18,19. This tectonic structure enables meteoric water to infiltrate to considerable depths, where it is heated and subsequently re-emerges as geothermal activity19. In the study area, geothermal manifestations result from convective water movement in the upper crust within a confined zone, where heat is transferred from the source to the surface under free-surface conditions8,20,21. The structural setup extends approximately 150 km northwest, hosting multiple geothermal resources19,22. These observations are consistent with the high heat-flow anomalies recorded along the MCT in the Garhwal Himalaya, which are associated with numerous hot springs and geothermal fields occurrences11,22.During electricity production, hot water gradually releases its heat, leading to a progressive decline in temperature6. However, the remaining thermal energy can be harnessed for various purposes, such as geothermal cooling, greenhouse farming, space heating, snow melting, geothermal heat pumps, district heating, industrial applications, gas and mineral extraction, and balneotherapy (e.g., lagoon tourism and spa facilities) through a cascade utilization approach. Geothermal resource assessment integrates surface manifestation observations with geoscientific data, including geophysical, geochemical, and geological analyses, to evaluate such potential23.Geothermal resource assessment techniques can be classified into four primary categories: (1) surface thermal flux, (2) volume, (3) planar fracture, and (4) magmatic heat budget. The volume method proves particularly effective due to its broad applicability, the capacity to accurately measure or estimate parameters, manageable error assessment, and the potential to address uncertainties related to recoverability and recharge through future modeling and engineering techniques24. This approach enhances the reliability of geothermal assessments and facilitates sustainable resource management.Estimating geothermal reservoir resources is primarily based on stored heat and volumetric methods, with Monte Carlo simulation widely regarded as the most reliable resource estimation25. The volumetric method evaluates the thermal energy of the system by treating the reservoir as a unified body or dividing it into layers and smaller blocks, each assigned unique values for essential parameters. Key parameters include temperature, porosity, area, thickness, density, and the heat capacity of the fluid and rock matrix26. By applying Monte Carlo simulation, uncertainties in these parameters can be quantified, resulting in more accurate and dependable estimates27. This integration of probabilistic modeling enhances the reliability of resource evaluation and improves decision-making in geothermal energy development.The Monte Carlo method demonstrates how randomness can inform decisions in the face of uncertainty. By repeatedly simulating outcomes for unknown variables, it generates statistically robust results through numerous iterations. For example, rolling a die produces possible outcomes ranging from 1 to 6, but the exact result remains unpredictable, highlighting the role of chance. Similarly, geothermal reservoir parameters such as area, thickness, porosity, and temperature also exist within a range of possible values, each carrying inherent uncertainty27.To achieve accurate results, these uncertainties are modeled using suitable probability distributions (e.g., normal, triangular, uniform, or log-normal) based on the specific characteristics of the geothermal field under investigation. The simulation then generates many random values for each parameter, which are processed iteratively until the results converge into a reliable estimate28. By combining sampling theory with numerical analysis, Monte Carlo simulation has evolved into a powerful tool in computational science, enabling detailed quantification of complex geothermal systems with high precision29.The widespread adoption of Monte Carlo Simulation (MCS) in geothermal research is primarily because of advancements in computing, which enable complex simulations that were previously labor-intensive30,31. This approach allows known geothermal resource characteristics to be projected into potential distributions within the same area30,32. A similar approach, the volumetric heat-in-place method, was initially developed by the United States Geological Survey (USGS)24,33 and later refined by34,35,36.In this study, the volumetric heat-in-place method is combined with Monte Carlo simulation to evaluate uncertainties in estimating the geothermal power potential of the Badrinath geothermal field in the Garhwal Himalaya, India. The assessment incorporates surface manifestations, geochemical and geophysical analyses, geological surveys, and dissolved silica thermometry data. The findings indicate a substantial geothermal potential, suggesting that Badrinath is well-suited for developing a pilot geothermal heating system to meet local energy demands.Geological setup, data, and methodsStudy areaRegions with high geothermal gradients, such as tectonically active areas or plate boundaries, commonly display geothermal anomalies13,19,21,37,38. A geothermal system consists of three key components: a heat source, a reservoir, and a transfer medium, usually a fluid that transports heat to the surface39,40. In India, notable geothermal regions are found in the Himalayas, primarily in deeply incised river valleys and along major geological structures, including the Indus-Tsangpo Suture Zone (ITSZ) and Main Central Thrust (MCT)19. The rapid uplift and erosion of the Himalayan range have resulted in a steep geothermal gradient, mainly driven by hydrothermal activity41,42. Magnetotelluric surveys in the Garhwal region of the northwest Himalayas have identified low-resistivity layers at an average depth of 5 kilometers22. Across India, approximately 300 geothermal springs or fields have been identified, with nearly half (about 120) located in the Himalayan region13,19,37,38.The ITSZ defines the northern boundary of the Himalayan orogeny, while the Himalayan Frontal Thrust (HFT) marks its southern limit43. This region is divided into four primary litho-tectonic units, separated by south-dipping intercontinental thrusts, including the South Tibet Detachment (STD), (MCT), and the Main Boundary Thrust (MBT)44. Notable geothermal activity in the Garhwal Himalaya is concentrated around the MCT zone, which is characterized by high heat flow (130 ± 30 mW/m2) and steep temperature gradients (60° ± 20 °C/km) in the northwest Himalaya45. In the Alaknanda Valley, geothermal features are associated with rock types such as gneiss, schist, and quartzite, all belonging to the Central Himalayan Crystallines46. This site contains gneiss, schist interbedded with calc-silicate, calc-schist, marble, and quartzite, all part of the central crystalline group47. The rocks exhibit asymmetrical folding, forming anticlines and synclines (Fig. 1).Fig. 1Study area with the location of the Badrinath geothermal field (modified after Tiwari et al.19).Full size imageThe Garhwal region of the northwest Himalayas is influenced by the Indian summer monsoon (I.S.M.) and westerly winds, which impact the rivers and streams in the area. The two major proglacial tributaries of the Ganga River system, Alaknanda and Bhagirathi, drain an area of approximately 30,000 km2.Badrinath is home to a single geothermal spring, strategically located on the right bank of the Alaknanda River at a remarkable elevation of 3089 m above sea level. This spring emerges from morainic deposits and is elegantly enclosed by a dome-like structure, along with other permanent installations37. The water, consistently heated to 55.6 °C, flows into various Kunds, serving as a vital resource for pilgrims. It is characteristically tasteless, possesses a distinct sulfurous odor, and occasionally contains gas bubbles, adding to its unique appeal. With an impressive flow rate of approximately 400 L per minute19, this spring not only fulfills spiritual needs but also showcases striking geological features, including visible carbonate deposits near the Tapta Kund, while displaying no ferruginous staining (Fig. 1). Located just 50 m downstream, a second spring with a gentle temperature of 20 °C offers its unique attributes. Its exact origin remains unclear, obscured by surrounding permanent structures. This colorless, slightly sour water is used for practical purposes such as bathing and laundry, with a notable discharge rate of around 190 L per minute. Collectively, these springs enhance Badrinath’s spiritual significance and highlight the region’s fascinating natural phenomena. About 50 m downstream, a lukewarm spring with a temperature of 20 °C also exists. Its precise origin is unclear due to surrounding permanent structures. The water is colorless, slightly sour, and used for bathing and laundry, with a discharge rate of approximately 190 L per minute.The study area has a cold-temperate climate, with snowfall occurring in the upper valleys during December and January, leading to the emergence of springs19,48,49. The study area lies within the inner Himalayan Range, characterized by rugged terrain with steep hills and deep valleys, with elevations ranging from 1400 to 6596 m above sea level. The region has a cold-temperate climate, and snowfall occurs in the upper reaches of the valleys during December and January. The monsoon season, spanning June to September, brings the heaviest rainfall, with an annual average of 1000 mm and 1200 mm48. Additionally, the region is considered highly promising for geothermal energy exploration37.The primary objective of geothermal resource assessments is to determine geothermal resources’ long-term power generation potential while ensuring sustainable utilization for at least 50 years. Accordingly, resource management strategies are designed to support long-term production. These assessments are generally performed during the reconnaissance and exploration phases before drilling, where data are synthesized to identify potential heat sources and host reservoirs, which are later confirmed through exploratory drilling at both shallow and deep levels.Geochemical characteristicsGeothermal systems exhibit rock-water interactions at moderate to high temperatures, with noticeable effects on the Earth’s surface. These interactions are often reflected in the chemical composition of spring water, making it a valuable indicator for studying geothermal systems. The water from Badrinath geothermal spring is mildly neutral, with a pH of 7 to 7.2. At 25 °C, its enormous specific conductivity is 2690 micromhos/cm, while the total dissolved solids (TDS) content is 1910 mg/L. This geochemical characteristic suggests its deep circulation has a meteoric origin19. The surface temperature of the geothermal spring water is recorded at 55.5°C19,37,49. The concentrations of various constituents (in mg/L) are detailed in Table 1.Table 1 The concentration of chemical constituents in the geothermal water of Badrinath19,37.Full size tableThe volumetric ‘‘heat in place’’ method for geothermal resourceEvaluating geothermal resources requires analyzing each area’s location, size, and geological characteristics. This information is crucial for estimating the accessible resource base, the thermal energy stored in the reservoir, and the recoverable thermal energy. The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) volumetric “heat in place” method is the most effective way to assess the energy potential of geothermal reservoirs. This reliable approach highlights the substantial resources available for sustainable energy production, underscoring the importance of geothermal energy in renewable solutions50. This study used the volume method to determine the stored energy and produced heat energy of a low-temperature geothermal reservoir in Badrinath. Microsoft Excel was utilized to conduct Monte Carlo simulation studies.The volume method is a highly effective strategy for calculating the thermal energy contained within a specific volume of rock and water, enabling a robust estimation of energy recovery potential. This method accurately determines the thermal energy in the ground by multiplying the volume of a geothermal reservoir by its mean temperature, porosity, and the specific heats of both rock and water. Alternatively, a more straightforward calculation can be employed using the volume, temperature, and an assumed volumetric specific heat51,52.While assessing recoverable thermal energy introduces more complexity, requiring an in-depth understanding of critical reservoir properties such as permeability, this challenge is well worth overcoming. In many cases, the recovery factor can only be approximated53, but the insights gained are invaluable. Notably, the volume method has proven highly effective in estimating thermal energy from low-temperature geothermal fields, underscoring its essential role in advancing sustainable energy solutions35.The volumetric method enhances this by combining MCS with the reservoir volume method24,33,34,35,36. Here, the volumetric method is adopted to estimate the geothermal power potential. The governing equations for total energy E in a geothermal system are given by:$${E}_{res} ={E}_{rock} + {E}_{fluid}$$
 (1)
 $${E}_{rock }={V(1-\varnothing )}_{{\rho }_{rock} }\times {C}_{rock}\times \left({T}_{res }-{T}_{reference}\right)$$
 (2)
 $${E}_{fluid }={(V\times \varnothing )}_{{\rho }_{fluid} }\times {C}_{fluid}\times \left({T}_{res }-{T}_{reference}\right)$$
 (3)
 or$${E}_{fluid }={(V\times \varnothing )}_{{\rho }_{fluid} }\times \left({T}_{res }-{T}_{reference}\right)$$
 (4)
 where.\({E}_{res}\) = Total energy in the reservoir (J);\({E}_{rock}\) = Energy in the reservoir rock (J);\({E}_{fluid}\) = Energy in the reservoir fluid (J);\({T}_{res}\) = Reservoir temperature (°C);\({T}_{reference}\) = Reference temperature (°C);V = Reservoir volume calculated (m3);Ø = porosity (fraction);Ϲ = Heat capacity (J/kg°C);Ρ = Density (kg/m3);հ = Enthalpy (J/kg).Total recoverable thermal energy is given by:$${E}_{recoverable }=A\times R\times {E}_{res}$$
 (5)
 where A = Accessibility, and R = Recovery factor.Therefore, thermal power \({P}_{thermal},\) the electrical energy capacity \({E}_{e}\) and power capacity \({P}_{e}\) can be determined by using:$${P}_{thermal} = \frac{{E}_{recoverable}}{\Delta T}$$
 (6)
 $${E}_{e}={\eta }_{e}\times {E}_{recoverable} \left(above reference temperature\right)$$
 (7)
 $${P}_{e} =\frac{{E}_{e}}{\Delta T}$$
 (8)
 where,$${P}_{thermal }=Thermal Power \left(W\right);$$$${P}_{electric }=Power capacity \left(W\right);$$$${E}_{e}=Electircal energy capacity;$$$${\eta }_{e }=Efficiency of the power plant;$$$${\Delta }_{t }=Utilization time period.$$Monte Carlo simulation (MCS)The MCS employs stochastic techniques to assess the impact of measurements and uncertainties on petrophysical results. This technique is preferred because it allows the interpretation model to be processed multiple times with randomly varied parameters. It is often used when the model is complex, nonlinear, or contains uncertain parameters. While the method incorporates various approaches, they generally follow a common pattern. MCS is reliable and widely adopted in geothermal resource assessment, power generation, and techno-economic evaluations. It relies on the reservoir volume method and iterative sampling of probability distributions (e.g., uniform, triangular, Gaussian, PERT). It helps to estimate the probability and cumulative distributions of geothermal resources, with P90, P50, and P10 values representing 90%, 50%, and 10% probability outcomes54,55.Key steps in (MCS) calculation
 
 Selection or development of a probability model based on statistical data, analogies, and theoretical considerations.
 
 
 Generation of random numbers and their corresponding random variables.
 
 
 Design and implementation of variance reduction techniques to improve computational efficiency.
 
 Input parameters for MCSIn this study, the collected data comprise reservoir temperature, formation thickness, porosity, formation rock density, specific heat, and the specific heat of formation fluid. These parameters are characterized using either uniform or triangular probability distributions. For the triangular distribution, each parameter is defined by its minimum, most likely, and maximum values, which makes this distribution particularly suitable when available data are limited35,56. Accordingly, triangular distributions are employed for density, specific heat capacity of rock, geothermal manifestation area, reservoir temperature, project lifespan, and reservoir lithology thickness. Uniform distributions are assigned to rock porosity and recovery factor, whereas constant distributions are used for hot water’s specific heat capacity and density, conversion efficiency, accessibility, and reference temperature. The MCS assessed the geothermal resource and power potential over 25, 35, and 50 years. The MCS runs with at least 100,000 iterations in Microsoft Excel. A comprehensive summary of all input parameters19,37 is provided in Tables 2 and 3.Table 2 Details of resistivity data of Badrinath Geothermal field, Garhwal Himalaya.Full size tableTable 3 Details of input parameters for the Monte Carlo volumetric assessment for 25, 35, and 50 years.Full size tableReservoir area and thicknessThe data range of the reservoir area has been selected based on the surface manifestation of geothermal activity according to19,37. In the Badrinath area, the lower order resistivity zone, having a resistivity range of 60 to 250 Ohm-meter with thickness ranging from 20 to 250 m, is indicated. The lowest resistivity, 60 Ohm-m, is recorded nearest to the hot spring manifestation (Table 2). This conductive zone appears to be significant from the point of view of geothermal potential. This zone’s resistivity may be lowered because of the heating effect of the hot fluids or the saturation57. The active geothermal area spreads over ~ 3 km2 (Fig. 1) between Bamni village (south of Badrinath) and Mana village (north of Badrinath Town).Reservo

items.title: Enhancing hydropower resilience through dynamic rule curve modifications under climate change in the Sunkoshi multipurpose scheme, Nepal
items.body:
IntroductionAmong the numerous challenges confronting the 21st century, climate change stands as one of the most pressing issues, primarily driven by anthropogenic activities1. Our globe has witnessed enormous changes over the past few decades through evidence such as rising global temperatures, extreme rainfall patterns, extreme weather events, and numerous impacts on the life that resides on this planet including humans2. Beyond climate variability that occurs naturally, human-induced climate variation has had extensive negative effects on nature and people, including more frequent and powerful extreme events3. The possible consequences of climate change will be more visible in the Himalayan region, where glacier melt and snowmelt dominate flow4. Snowmelt contributes about 20% of annual stream flow in the Hindu Kush-Himalayan area, with a maximum contribution of \(\:>\)65% in the Indus watershed5. In the Sunkoshi basin, snowmelt contributes 6.1% and glacier runoff 10.5% of the total runoff, with snowmelt and baseflow together providing over 81.6% during the high crop water demand pre-monsoon period, while glacier runoff peaks at 11.5% from July to September6. Global warming intensifies the hydrological cycle, resulting in an accelerated rate of glacier and snowmelt in cryospheric-dominated basins. This process subsequently enhances downstream runoff, influencing water availability and hydrological regimes. This variability has consequences for both reservoir and Run off River (RoR) hydropower plants, the latter being more sensitive as the availability of flow varies with time as a result of climate change7.In 2022, global installed hydropower capacity increased by 26 GW to 1360 GW8. According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), hydropower will provide around 15% of global electricity generation in 2023–2030, with an average annual generation growth rate of close to 4%9. Also, Nepal’s hydroelectric generation increased significantly in FY2023, adding 500 MW for the second year in a row10. Nepal generated 1,050 MW of hydropower till 2012, and by 2023, this capacity had expanded to 2,800 MW, demonstrating remarkable development11. Developing a portion of Nepal’s hydropower potential has been shown to result in robust economic growth, significantly reducing poverty in the process12. Despite its potential benefits, Nepal’s hydroelectric growth is sensitive to climate change, which may have economic consequences13. The direct cost associated with the current climate variability and extreme events has been estimated to be equivalent to 1.5–2% of the current GDP/year and will be much higher in extreme years anticipated to rise by 5% or more which is higher as per the international levels14. So, the economic advancement and the overall prosperity of a nation directly or indirectly depend on how the natural resources, notably water, within the specific context of countries like Nepal are managed by their planners and policymakers through strategic decisions to ensure sustainable utilization of these crucial resources. Also, climate change may modify past hydrological patterns, leading to spatial and temporal variability in water flowing through rivers15. The predictability of water availability is hindered by this unpredictability, making it perplexing to optimize hydropower generation schedules. In the pursuit of optimizing energy generation, an assessment of the impacts due to climate variability and fluctuation in the river discharge becomes crucial.Nepal’s complex geology and varied topography render it highly vulnerable to climate change, particularly in terms of glacial dynamics and shifting precipitation patterns. These factors play a critical role in regulating river discharge, with profound implications for hydropower generation, agricultural productivity, and rural livelihoods16. Numerous researches have been conducted in several major river basins of Nepal by a number of researchers considering different General Circulation models (GCMs) developed by Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP) and considering various emission scenarios. By the end of the century, Nepal’s average surface temperature is projected to increase by approximately 5.8 °C17. In the mid-term, temperature rises are expected to range between 0.9 °C and 1.1 °C, while long-term projections indicate an increase of 1.3 °C to 1.8 °C18. As a result of the temperature rise, the snowcaps are likely to melt more quickly ultimately leading to extreme events such as pluvial floods and glacier lake outburst flooding, eventually causing damage to hydraulic structures that are intended to be constructed in the river. According to a study carried out for the West Seti River basin of Nepal, water yield was likely to escalate as a consequence of an upsurge in precipitation, with high flows anticipated to increase and conversely, low flows projected to decrease19. Similarly, fluctuations in the flow from a seasonal point of view are also vital. Despite the uncertainty and unpredictability associated with the assessment of climate variability, pre-monsoon and monsoon seasons are more likely to experience an upsurge, particularly during the monsoon season, which could cause widespread damage to infrastructure, livelihoods, and settlements in the future20. Also, future projections based on Regional Climate Models (RCMs) suggest a decrease of over 30% in monthly flow during drier months and an increase of more than 25% during high flow months compared to baseline values for the Koshi River Basin21. The synergistic effect of higher temperatures and increased precipitation leads to a 50% rise in discharge at the Kaligandaki River basin outlet, largely attributed to a projected 90% increase in snowmelt by the 2090s22. Climate-induced changes in temperature and precipitation in the Karnali River Basin are projected to increase future water availability, with annual discharge expected to rise by 6.4–8.4% under RCP 4.5 and by 5.1–10.9% under RCP 8.5 by 2040–2099, especially during pre-monsoon and monsoon seasons, likely intensifying later in the century23.Numerous studies that have been conducted for the comprehensive evaluation of climate change impact significantly in the context of river basins in Nepal were executed using the GCMs that were developed by CMIP5 and the Representative Concentration Pathways scenarios. Recently a new collection of scenarios has been created for ScenarioMIP, the section of the global CMIP6 of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP) that includes scenario runs for the twenty-first century and these scenarios are known as Shared Socio-economic Pathways (SSP). This study attempts to consider the new SSP scenarios for the study, which will help visualize the climate change variations based on both socioeconomic as well as Greenhouse Gas (GHG) concentrations. High-resolution CMIP6 models provide improved simulations of precipitation patterns and temperature variability, capturing regional climate phenomena more accurately24. Additionally, updated parameterizations of physical processes, including cloud microphysics, aerosols, and land-surface interactions like vegetation dynamics and soil moisture, enhance the models’ ability to represent land-atmosphere interactions effectively25. While the models used in this study—GCMs, Soil and Water Assessment Tool (SWAT), and Hydrologic Engineering Center’s Reservoir System Simulation (HEC-ResSim)—are widely applied in hydrological and climate change research, this study provides a unique contribution by integrating these tools in a novel way to address the challenges of climate change impacts on hydropower operations in Nepal. The SWAT model is widely used globally for hydrological studies due to its ability to simulate comprehensive processes and its user-friendly interface, making it ideal for diverse applications26. Additionally, the SWAT-CUP program’s semi-automated technique (SUFI-2) can assist users in performing more thorough sensitivity and uncertainty analysis27. HEC-ResSim is a software developed by the US Army Corps of Engineers, Hydrological Engineering Center (HEC) with US Federal Government resources28. HEC-ResSim is a multi-reservoir simulation model, effectively models water resource systems29. The SWAT-HEC-ResSim-GA framework underpins resilient reservoir management by enhancing understanding of complex systems and enabling uncertainty assessment from various sources across decision-making phases, fostering informed and adaptive water resource planning and operation30. Khatri et al. (2024)31 optimizes the reservoir operation in the Tamor basin storage project strategies using particle-swarm optimization, adapting to altered streamflow, mitigating pre-monsoon flow deficits, and enhancing annual energy generation and downstream dry-season flows. Previous studies have primarily focused on evaluating alterations in discharge and power generation within hydropower projects, neglecting to propose effective adaptation strategies in response to climate change. For instance, Pradhan et al. (2021)17 mainly focus on evaluation of CMIP5 GCMs for precipitation and temperature simulations in the Koshi River Basin. Budhathoki et al. (2021)19 assessed changes in water balance and hydrological extremes in the West Seti Basin but provided limited adaptation insights, and Dahal et al. (2020)23 modeled climate change impacts on water availability in the Karnali Basin. Operational strategies for hydropower adaptation are further needed. Consequently, it is imperative to develop an adaptation strategy, especially for complex projects like the Sunkoshi multipurpose project, which encompasses the construction of four distinct reservoir-type projects in series.This study aims to examine the alterations in the climate variables using seven GCMs developed by CMIP6 under SSP245 and SSP585 scenarios. The impact of these alterations in the hydrological regime of the Sunkoshi River basin will be evaluated by examining the alterations in the flow and ultimately to the hydropower generations of four planned reservoir-type projects, namely Sunkoshi No.1, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.3 and Dudhkoshi. Furthermore, this study seeks to propose dynamic rule curves for cascading reservoirs in the Sunkoshi Basin to ensure sustainable and efficient hydropower generation. Unlike previous studies that primarily assessed the impacts of climate change on hydropower without proposing adaptive strategies, this study integrates dynamic rule curve modifications using climate projections and reservoir operation simulations. By iteratively adjusting reservoir levels based on projected flow changes, this study bridges the gap between hydrological modeling and real-time hydropower management, offering a novel operational framework for climate adaptation.Materials and methodsStudy areaThe Sunkoshi River Basin is a transboundary basin shared by Tibet (China) and Nepal, encompassing the catchment areas of key tributaries, including Bhote Koshi, Indravati, Tamakoshi, Likhu, and Dudhkoshi. Originating from the Zhangzangbo Glacier in Tibet32, the Sunkoshi River flows into Nepal, where the Indravati River joins it near Dolaghat. The river then meanders eastward through the valley formed by the Mahabharat Range and the Himalayas32. At Tribenighat, the Sunkoshi converges with the Tamur and Arun rivers to form the Saptakoshi. The basin extends from 85°23’13.2’’ E to 87°9’25.2’’ E longitude and 28°31’26.4’’ N to 26°34’58.8’’ N latitude, with elevation ranging from 111 to 8777 masl with catchment area of approximately 18,140 km2. This study deals with the four proposed Storage type projects: Sunkoshi No.3, Sunkoshi No.2, Sunkoshi No.1, and Dudhkoshi Hydropower projects. Figure 1 shows the study area map, highlighting the location of these four storage-type projects planned to be constructed in the Sunkoshi River basin. Table 1 provides a summary of the salient features of these four reservoir-type projects. Additionally, the basin includes two inter-basin transfer initiatives: the Sunkoshi Marin Diversion Multipurpose Project (SMDMP) and the Sunkoshi Kamala Diversion Multipurpose Project (SKDMP).Fig. 1Study Area Map showing Sunkoshi River Basin, Nepal.Full size imageTable 1 Salient features of storage type projects proposed by JICA33,34.Full size tableDataHydro-meteorological and temperature dataDaily hydrological data from 1990 to 2014 AD of stations located at Pachuwarghat, Rabuwa bazar, and Hampachuwar and meteorological data for the same period from 13 stations within the basin were collected from the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM), Nepal. However, most of these stations were located in lower-elevation regions, necessitating the integration of data from higher-altitude areas for a more comprehensive representation. To address this limitation, precipitation data from the Asian Precipitation–Highly-Resolved Observational Data Integration Towards Evaluation of Extreme Events (APHRODITE) database were incorporated. The reliability of APHRODITE’s daily precipitation estimates over Nepal was rigorously evaluated through comparative analysis with ground-based gauge observations35. Similarly, daily maximum and minimum temperature data of three stations: Dhulikhel, Jiri, and Okhaldhunga were collected and further used in the analysis.Digital Elevation Model (DEM), Land use and Land cover (LULC), and Soil data for hydrological modelingSWAT model requires DEM, LULC map, and Soil map for the preparation of a hydrological model7. NASA Digital Elevation Model (NASADEM) was downloaded from NASA’s official website and used for the watershed delineation. The LULC map for the Hindu Kush Himalayan (HKH) region as of 2010 AD was acquired from the International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD) website with an equivalent scale of 1:50,000. The soil Map for the basin was downloaded from the official website of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) for the United Nations. These maps were processed and clipped to the basin area using ArcGIS v.10.8.2 software. The resulting DEM, LULC, and soil maps are shown in Fig. 2.Fig. 2a DEM, b LULC, c Soil Map for the Sunkoshi River basin.Full size imageProjected climate dataIn this study, seven bias-corrected datasets from CMIP6-GCMs for the historic (1951–2014) and projected (2015–2100) climates for the two scenarios (SSP245, SSP585) were used. Mishra et al. (2020) have developed the daily bias-corrected data of precipitation, maximum and minimum temperature at 0.25° spatial resolution for South Asia and 18 river basins located in the Indian sub-continent36. SSP245 considers a middle of the road pathway which depicts an intermediate scenario with moderate challenges to mitigation and adaptation, population growth, substantial divergence in income trends among nations, and a level of cooperation between states, while SSP585 illustrates a high-emission, fossil-fuel-driven future with significant challenges. Together, these scenarios encompass a spectrum from low-mid to high emissions, allowing researchers to assess various climate impacts and uncertainties effectively37 and hence were selected for this study. The GCMs used in the research include ACCESS-CM2, BCC-CSM2-MR, CanESM5, EC-Earth3, MPI-ESM1-2-HR, MPI-ESM1-2-LR, and NorESM2-MM. The selection of GCMs for this study was based on multiple criteria to ensure robust climate projections over the Sunkoshi River basin. The chosen seven GCMs mentioned above were selected based on the following factors:
 
 i)
 
 Performance in South Asia and the Himalayan Region: These models have been widely used in climate impact studies due to their ability to simulate monsoon variability and high-altitude climate processes, both of which are critical for hydropower assessment in Nepal.
 
 
 
 ii)
 
 Bias-Corrected Data Availability: The selected GCMs have high-resolution, bias-corrected datasets for South Asia36, which enhances their applicability for hydrological modeling.
 
 
 
 iii)
 
 Diversity in Model Structures and Origins: The selected models represent different modeling institutions and methodologies, reducing dependency on a single climate modeling framework and capturing a broader range of possible climate futures.
 
 
 
 iv)
 
 Use in Previous Studies: These GCMs have been utilized in prior hydrological and climate studies in Nepal and the South Asian region, ensuring their reliability in similar applications.
 
 
 
 v)
 
 Ensemble Approach for Uncertainty Reduction: Since individual GCMs may contain biases or uncertainties, using multiple models helps provide a more representative range of future climate conditions, minimizing the influence of outliers.
 
 
 Reservoir system dataPhysical and operation data for the simulation of reservoir operation are required as an input in the HEC-ResSim38 that includes Elevation-Area-Volume (E-A-V) data, routing parameters, dam and spillway data, and information on evaporation and seepage losses. These datasets were acquired from reports prepared by the Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA) and prior studies carried out for these hydropower projects33,34.MethodologyThe prime focus of this study is to study the variations in precipitation, temperature, and discharge patterns across the past, present, and future time series and present a strategy for the operation of four substantial planned hydropower reservoirs in the Sunkoshi river basin that adapts to the varying climatic and flow patterns. To accomplish the objective of this study, the adopted methodology involved a series of stepwise sub procedures. These procedures incorporated the future climate projection employing a bias correction method, the development of a hydrological model in ArcSWAT 10.8, and finally the simulation of reservoir operation through HEC-ResSim 3.3 software. Figure 3 represents the adopted methodological framework.Projection of future climate scenariosThe future climate variables, specifically precipitation and temperature, were forecasted using downscaled GCMs developed by Mishra et al. (2020)36. The selected seven GCMs precipitation and temperature data underwent downscaling at local station levels, considering two distinct scenarios, SSP245 and SSP585. Since, the GCMs models possess higher resolutions, they tend to fail to imitate climate data at the basin scale due to biasness39. Therefore, bias correction is necessary to align the simulated data more closely with observed conditions before conducting impact assessments40.Temperature and precipitation simulations frequently exhibit significant biases due to systematic model errors or discretization and spatial averaging within grid cells, limiting the use of simulated climate data as direct input data for hydrological models40. To minimize the dissimilarity between observed and simulated quantities on a daily time step, bias correction processes were employed such that the model reflects the real-time phenomenon pretty well41. For this study, CMhyd software was employed for bias correction and downscaling the regional climate model to the local scale. CMhyd identifies biases between observed and simulated historical climate data and applies the same correction factors to future projections to ensure compatibility with hydrological models41. Among the various correction methods available for bias correction, Linear scaling (Multiplicative) and Linear scaling (Additive) were employed for precipitation and temperature variables respectively. The linear scaling method is comparatively simple for application and has almost similar accuracy as compared to the complex ones39. Furthermore, the effectiveness of the bias correction in these models was assessed by comparing the observed DHM data and the bias-corrected data through three statistical indices: Nash–Sutcliffe simulation efficiency (NSE), percentage bias (PBIAS), and coefficient of determination (R2) for three climate

Le Associazioni ambientaliste Greenpeace, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF hanno presentato un nuovo reclamo all’Unione Europea  denunciando come si vorrebbe realizzare il Ponte sullo Stretto di Messina senza procedere all’affidamento lavori tramite gara pubblica internazionale.
In particolare le Associazioni ritengono che ci sia una reiterata violazione da parte dell’Italia degli artt.101/109 del TFUE e dell’art.72 della Direttiva 2014/14/UE sulla concorrenza.  Il nuovo reclamo è il quarto presentato dalle Associazioni e si aggiunge a quello per la mancata applicazione della Direttiva sulla Valutazione Ambientale Strategica (Direttiva 2001/42/CE recepita in Italia dal Testo Unico Ambientale, Decreto Legislativo n. 152/2006) ed a quelli presentati avverso i due pareri della Commissione VIA VAS per la  non corretta applicazione della Direttiva 92/43/CEE  detta “HABITAT” e della  Direttiva  2009/147/CE per la  “Conservazione degli uccelli selvatici”.
Il nuovo reclamo ripropone il tema della mancata gara d’appalto internazionale per la realizzazione del Ponte contestando l’interpretazione normativa che è stata data per evitarla.  Infatti nonostante l’avvenuta messa in liquidazione della SdM avvenuta nel 2013 e i conseguenti atti caducati che regolavano i rapporti di concessione, il Governo ha inteso ripristinare integralmente i rapporti preesistenti facendo scegliere al Parlamento la soluzione di attraversamento stabile dello Stretto di Messina attraverso la realizzazione del ponte a campata unica progettato dal SdM sulla base dell’aggiudicazione dell’opera avvenuta 24 novembre 2005 e, inoltre, e sulla base di  un’offerta di 3,9 miliardi avanzata dal consorzio Eurolink. Al di là della condivisione o meno sulla scelta dell’opera (comunque contestata dalle Associazioni),  ed al di là dell’interpretazione che si può dare sulla soluzione di continuità avvenuta nel 2013 nei confronti della SdM e dei rapporti di  questa finalizzati alla realizzazione dell’opera,  il reclamo afferma che il Governo Italiano avrebbe dovuto procedere, invece, ad una nuova gara internazionale.  In particolare, si ritiene non corretto il  riferimento su cui è stato calcolato l’incremento dei costi  che la normativa vigente -per non procedere a nuova gara- ritiene ammissibile  sino ad un massimo del  50%.   L’appalto oggi stimato in oltre 13,5 miliardi  (per altro ampiamente sottostimati) secondo le Associazioni non può essere realizzato dallo stesso soggetto che nel 2005 lo aveva vinto per 3,9 miliardi su un progetto che poi avrebbe subito progressive  modifiche e un’importante estensione delle opere connesse e di quelle compensative.
Il reclamo trasmette all’Unione Europea la posizione ed i documenti dall’ANAC che, anche in sede di audizioni parlamentari, aveva sollevato dubbi sulla mancata applicazione della Direttiva concorrenza e quindi sulla mancata nuova gara internazionale. L’ANAC sul tema dal 2023  è rimasta inascoltata sebbene nell’ultima audizione svolta alla Camera  il 9 giugno 2025 quindi ben prima della delibera CIPESS, tramite il suo Presidente Avv. Giuseppe Busia  abbia esplicitamente affermato:  “L’aver deciso di non svolgere una nuova gara in coincidenza della riattivazione del percorso per la costruzione del ponte sullo Stretto pone dei vincoli sui costi dell’opera: questi, infatti, non possono crescere oltre il 50% del valore originariamente messo a gara. Ciò, in base alla direttiva europea, che in certi casi consente di non attivare una nuova procedura concorrenziale, ma entro tali limiti”.
Le Associazioni ambientaliste Greenpeace, Legambiente, Lipu e WWF hanno poi inviato al CIPESS una nota con cui chiedono il ritiro in autotutela della delibera n. 41 del 6 agosto 2025 con cui il Governo ha chiuso l’iter di approvazione del Ponte, delibera ancora sospesa perché all’attenzione della Corte dei Conti che ha già avanzato puntuali rilievi.  Al di là delle risposte che il Governo fornirà ai rilievi della Corte dei Conti, la richiesta delle Associazioni elenca i  gravi elementi di criticità già esposti nei ricorsi presentati al TAR Lazio e nei reclami inoltrati all’Unione Europea. Le Associazioni sono consapevoli che già la Corte dei Conti  in assenza di risposte ai rilievi avanzati ha invitato il CIPESS a ritirare in autotutela la delibera n. 41 del 6 agosto 2025, ma ritengono che qualunque siano le risposte che verranno fornite all’interno del  controllo preventivo di legittimità queste non possano superare né tanto meno sanare le problematiche  ed i vizi del procedimento deliberativo del CIPESS.

items.title: Atlante anfibi e rettili, il 25 ottobre la presentazione a Roma
items.description:
Un Atlante completo e aggiornato sulla distribuzione di tutte le specie di anfibi e i rettili presenti in Italia
The post Atlante anfibi e rettili, il
items.body:
Pandanews
 
 

 

 
 
 Categorie
 

 
 
 

 
 Vi hanno collaborato oltre 100 esperti della Societas Herpetologica Italica, tra i quali il Presidente WWF Luciano Di Tizio
 
 
 

 

 
 
Appuntamento all’Università di Roma Sapienza

L’Italia annovera 54 specie di rettili (di cui il 19% minacciate) e 43 di anfibi (36% minacciate). Una specie di anfibio su 3 (ben 14) sono endemiche, vivono cioè solo nel nostro Paese. Proprio gli anfibi, a causa della distruzione delle zone umide, dei cambiamenti climatici e della introduzione di specie aliene, risultano essere la classe maggiormente minacciata, non solo nella nostra penisola ma a livello globale secondo l’IUCN, l’Unione Internazionale per la Conservazione della Natura. Per far luce su questi animali assai poco conosciuti se non osteggiati, è in arrivo il nuovo Atlante degli Anfibi e Rettili d’Italia, che sarà presentato il 25 ottobre a Roma. Un volume completo e aggiornato sulla distribuzione di tutti gli anfibi e i rettili presenti in Italia. Per ogni specie vengono fornite informazioni approfondite sulla biologia, l’ecologia e sullo stato di conservazione. 

Presentazione

Sabato 25 ottobre ore 10, 30 – Sapienza – Università di RomaDipartimento di Biologia e Biotecnologie Charles DarwinViale dell’Università, 32 – ROMA

Locandina presentazione Atlante

La redazione delle schede è stata affidata a oltre 100 esperti della Societas Herpetologica Italica, che hanno analizzato un imponente database composto da più di 265.000 segnalazioni, raccolte grazie al contributo di migliaia di osservatori. I testi sono arricchiti da splendide immagini di alta qualità, scattate in natura da fotografi-erpetologi. Il risultato è un’opera corale di grande valore scientifico, che costituisce un punto di riferimento fondamentale per studiosi, ricercatori e professionisti, ma anche una guida preziosa per gli appassionati e per chi vuole saperne di più su questi affascinanti animali.

The Original Article  was published on 08 October 2025

replying to R. Blackport & M. Sigmond Communications Earth & Environment https://doi.org/10.1038/s43247-025-02629-y (2025)Blackport and Sigmond1 argue that in Cohen et al.2 our method of computing trends on cold extremes (that is, keeping the definition of a cold extreme fixed over the entire period (coldest 5% of days 1960–2023)) artificially masked any warming trends in cold extremes. We chose this method to avoid the case where no trend appears in a limited period, for example, since 2000, but clearly, the cold extremes are warmer than in the previous period 1960–2000 due to the warming being more of a step function than a gradual trend. By keeping the definition of a cold extreme fixed across the entire period of analysis, we believed that would make it harder to identify a cold extreme in the latter milder winters. Alternatively, with a moving or non-fixed definition of a cold extreme in effect, we would be comparing cold extremes that were defined differently across periods, and not a consistently defined cold extreme.Blackport and Sigmond1 use synthetic data to demonstrate that, even with warming temperatures including cold extremes, by using a fixed threshold no statistically significant trends can be detected in cold extremes. If, instead, cold extremes are defined only within the period of analysis, then the warming trend in cold extremes can be correctly detected. We did consider computing the trend in cold extremes using a moving threshold as suggested by Blackport and Sigmond1 where cold extremes are computed only in the period for which the trend is being considered. We also acknowledge that no metric of measuring a trend in cold extremes is perfect, and multiple methods and metrics are likely needed for a comprehensive understanding of changes in cold extremes.We show box and whisker plots of Arctic and CEUS temperature, where cold extremes are computed for each decade separately in keeping with the guidance of Blackport and Sigmond1. In the Arctic (Fig. 1), both cold extremes and mean temperatures have steadily warmed, and post-2010, none of the observed cold extremes reach the extremity of the warmest cold extremes observed before 1980. In the CEUS (Fig. 2), the box and whisker plot does not resemble so much a linear warming trend across the decades but more like a step function with cold extremes and mean temperatures steady from 1960 through 1990 and again steady from 1990 through the present at a warmer temperature. Visually there is no trend in cold extremes during the period of AA (post-1990) in the CEUS, even though a moving threshold is applied. And in stark contrast to Arctic temperatures, cold extremes in the CEUS in the most recent decade are comparable to those from the previous five decades going back to 1960. Though from Fig. 2 the mean temperature of cold extremes is higher during the period of AA than before the period of AA.Fig. 1: Boxplots (25–75th percentiles) of the coldest 5% 2-meter temperatures in the Arctic region (70–90°N) for each decade 1960–2023.The threshold is applied for each decade separately.Full size imageFig. 2: Boxplots (25–75th percentiles) of the coldest 5% 2-meter temperatures in the CEUS region (30–50°N, 250–285°E) for each decade 1960–2023.The threshold is applied for each decade separately.Full size imageWe also note that Table 1 from Blackport and Sigmond1 (comparing a fixed threshold of cold extremes and a moving threshold of cold extremes) shows little difference in trends in cold extremes during the period of AA. In the CEUS, negative trends were found since 2000 for both methods, and in SSNC, the moving threshold resulted in a larger negative trend since 1990. In the period of AA for the CEUS and SSNC regions, only the trend in the CEUS since 1990 became statistically significant.In summary, we welcome the Blackport and Sigmond Matters Arising piece1 as it provides greater context to the trends in cold extremes across the mid-latitude continents. We emphasize that no single metric can fully capture the character and changes in extreme events. Our original paper of Cohen et al.2 and the criticism of Blackport and Sigmond1 demonstrate that identification and analysis of cold extremes are sensitive to the definition of a cold extreme. Future studies of cold extremes and trends provide greater context when multiple approaches to the analysis are used rather than just one.However, we also don’t feel that using an alternative trend computation of using a moving threshold of cold extremes negates our general conclusions that global warming has led to a detectable warming of cold extremes, but that warming is not consistent with AA in several mid-latitude locations. This is further supported by the fact that between the two methodologies for the CEUS and SSNC regions, in seven of the eight trends computed for the two definitions of the recent period, no statistically significant warming trend was found. Therefore, the alternative derivations of cold extremes in our study and that of Blackport and Sigmond1 do not necessarily produce contradictory results or conclusions. Moreover, our interpretation is not based solely on our analysis. A recent study on mid-latitude cold extremes corroborated our findings using a completely independent analysis of non-stationary generalized extreme value (GEV) distribution, which assumes non-stationary climate change as Blackport and Sigmond1 advocate. Ye et al.3 conclude: “These findings are in line with the conclusions of Cohen et al.2 that the changes in the frequency of winter cold events in some mid-latitude regions may be influenced mainly by global warming rather than by Arctic amplification”.

Data availability
              
              The ERA5 reanalysis data4 sets cover the period from 1950 to present with a resolution of approximately 30 km, which can be accessed at https://www.ecmwf.int/en/forecasts/dataset/ecmwf-reanalysis-v5.
